Expectation1: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation1: At the end of the shift, it's time for the routine sweep-up of your designated work area.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story:
I wiped the sweat from my brow as the foreman called out, “End of shift! Make sure your area’s spotless before you go.” My boots crunched over gravel as I grabbed the broom, glancing at the clock. I had just enough time to sweep up and rush to the polling station before it closed. The site rules were strict—no one left until their section was clean and safe. I didn’t want to let my crew down or risk a warning.

When I finally made it to the polling place, my hands still gritty, I signed my ballot envelope. The poll worker frowned. “Sorry, this is smudged. Please re-sign so your vote counts.” I hesitated, thinking of the safety protocols drilled into me at work—never touch anything with dirty hands, always keep things clean. But the poll worker was insistent, and the line behind me was growing. My mind raced between the demand to keep things clean and the duty to follow the voting process. I stood there, torn, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
